Nvidia and OpenAI have announced a massive partnership, with the US-based chipmaker committing to invest $100 billion in the ChatGPT-maker and supply it with advanced data centre chips. The deal brings together two of its most influential companies in the artificial intelligence (AI) sector.According to a report by news agency Reuters, the collaboration involves two separate but intertwined transactions. Nvidia will make an initial $10 billion investment in OpenAI for non-voting shares once a definitive agreement is reached.OpenAI, in turn, will use the capital to purchase Nvidia‚Äôs high-performance chips, an essential component for its AI development. The companies have signed a letter of intent to deploy at least 10 gigawatts of Nvidia systems for OpenAI, with plans to finalise the partnership in the coming weeks."Everything starts with compute. Compute infrastructure will be the basis for the economy of the future, and we will utilize what we're building with Nvidia to both create new AI breakthroughs and empower people and businesses with them at scale," said OpenAI CEO Sam Altman This alliance will provide Nvidia a significant financial stake in a key customer and solidifies its position as the leading chip supplier for AI development. For OpenAI, the investment guarantees both the funding and access to the advanced computing power necessary to maintain its competitive edge.The first gigawatt of computing power from the deal is expected to be deployed in the second half of 2026 on Nvidia‚Äôs upcoming platform, named Vera Rubin. The company will begin delivering hardware to OpenAI as soon as late 2026.While this partnership is a major development, it does not alter OpenAI‚Äôs existing plans to develop its own custom AI chips as a potential alternative to Nvidia's hardware. OpenAI has previously collaborated with Broadcom and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. on a custom chip design, a project that is expected to continue.

Article Title: "I've worked on H1-B politics for 30 years," Netflix co-founder says US' $100k H-1B tax is...
Article Text:
White House clarifies H-1B fees structure after a weekend of confusion





Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings has endorsed President Donald Trump's new $100,000 H-1B visa fee, breaking ranks with most Silicon Valley leaders who have criticised the policy as harmful to innovation and startup growth. In a post on X, Hastings wrote: "I've worked on H1-B politics for 30 years. Trump's $100k per year tax is a great solution. It will mean H1-B is used just for very high-value jobs, which will mean no lottery needed, and more certainty for those jobs."The H-1B program allows US companies to hire foreign workers in specialised roles, with 85,000 annual slots available despite over 400,000 applications. Current data shows nearly half of applications come from tech and science fields, with about 30% of roles paying $100,000 or less.Hastings' support stands out because he's a prominent Democratic megadonor who has previously criticised Trump, saying the president "would destroy much of what is great about America." His endorsement cuts against the dominant Silicon Valley sentiment, where tech leaders including Elon Musk have fiercely opposed the changes.However, Hastings incorrectly described the fee as annual. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt clarified Saturday that it's a one-time payment for new petitions only, not renewals or existing visa holders."This is NOT an annual fee," Leavitt posted on X, explaining the policy applies to new visas starting with the March 2026 lottery cycle.The weekend brought chaos across Silicon Valley after Trump signed the executive order Friday. Companies including Amazon , Microsoft, Google, and Tesla urged H-1B employees to stay in the U.S. or return before the Sunday deadline. At San Francisco airport, passengers reportedly deplaned from India-bound flights after learning about the new rules.While tech giants may absorb the costs, startups and smaller firms warn they'll be priced out of hiring international talent, potentially shortening their financial runway by months.
Article Summary: Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings has endorsed President Donald Trump's new $100,000 H-1B visa fee. His endorsement cuts against the dominant Silicon Valley sentiment, where tech leaders including Elon Musk have fiercely opposed the changes. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt clarified Saturday that it's a one-time payment.

Oracle will implement significant modifications to TikTok‚Äôs algorithm following an anticipated executive order from President Donald Trump later this week, a White House official confirmed. Under the proposed agreement to transfer TikTok‚Äôs US operations to a consortium of American investors, Oracle will be tasked with developing and securing a US-specific version of the platform‚Äôs algorithm.According to a report by Bloomberg, the plan has been outlined by the official and it will ensure that the new US-based owners will control TikTok's recommendation software ‚Äì which has been a complicating factor in any past deal.The official explained that the American buyers will lease a copy of the algorithm from TikTok's Chinese parent company, ByteDance, and Oracle will then "retrain" it "from the ground up."The agreement also specifies that all data from US users will be stored in a secure cloud managed by Oracle. The specific extent of the government's oversight role, however, was not immediately clear.This news comes as President Donald Trump prepares to finalise a long-awaited plan to sell the video-sharing platform.

Article Title: European Commission plans to end this 16-year-old law for websites
Article Text:
Tech giants want one-click cookie settings across all websites

Privacy watchdogs sound alarm over surveillance advertising expansion





The European Commission is planning to eliminate the annoying cookie consent banners that have cluttered websites across the internet for over 15 years, according to Politico. The move is part of Brussels' broader effort to slash digital red tape and simplify technology regulations.The proposed changes would target the 2009 e-Privacy Directive, which requires websites to obtain user consent before loading cookies‚Äîsmall data files that track visitor behavior and preferences. The rule created the ubiquitous pop-up banners that users now automatically click through without reading."Too much consent basically kills consent," data lawyer Peter Craddock told Politico. "People are used to giving consent for everything, so they might stop reading things in as much detail."The Commission held industry meetings this week to discuss alternatives, including allowing users to set cookie preferences once in their browser settings rather than on every website visit. Denmark has suggested dropping consent requirements for cookies used for "technically necessary functions" or "simple statistics," which officials consider "harmless" compared to marketing trackers.Tech industry representatives want cookie rules moved from the strict e-Privacy Directive to the more flexible General Data Protection Regulation ( GDPR ), which uses a risk-based approach to privacy protection.The proposal sets up a fierce lobbying fight between industry and privacy advocates. European Digital Rights warned that expanding exceptions for "essential" tracking could "smuggle in analytics or personalization for adtech."The Commission plans to present its omnibus deregulation package in December, with further privacy battles expected when it introduces the Digital Fairness Act next year. The cookie law reform represents President Ursula von der Leyen's latest attempt to balance privacy protection with European tech competitiveness.Previous efforts to reform cookie consent rules stalled in 2017, with the original e-Privacy Regulation proposal withdrawn earlier this year after years of institutional deadlock.
Article Summary: The European Commission is planning to eliminate the annoying cookie consent banners that have cluttered websites for over 15 years. The move is part of Brussels' broader effort to slash digital red tape and simplify technology regulations. The proposed changes would target the 2009 e-Privacy Directive, which requires websites to obtain user consent.

Article Title: How a technical glitch in Income tax website may cost crores to several companies
Article Text:
What the tax rules say





A technical glitch in the Income Tax department ‚Äôs website prevented several companies from completing their advance tax payments by the September 15 deadline, leaving them exposed to steep penalties. According to a report by Economic Times, advisors and counsels have approached the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) and the finance ministry, requesting waiver of interest for payments that were initiated on or before September 15 but could not be processed. Some firms are also considering writ petitions if relief is not provided, tax practitioners told the publication.Under tax rules, late payment of advance tax attracts interest at 1% per month. Since advance tax is paid quarterly, even a single day‚Äôs delay results in a 3% charge. For large taxpayers, the penalty can run into several crores.This year, September 15 was both the last date for filing income tax returns for assessment year 2024‚Äì25 and the deadline for the second installment of advance tax, creating an additional load on the portal.The ET report quotes senior chartered accountant Gautam Nayak who said, ‚ÄúWhile extending the ITR due date by a day, the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) did not extend the due date for advance tax payments.The same portal is used for tax payments as well, following the integration of the filing and payment portals. Many taxpayers could not log in to pay advance tax. Several of them were unable to complete payment due to the glitches in the portal. They would be penalised with a 3 per cent interest for no fault of theirs. The CBDT should waive the otherwise mandatory levy of interest in cases where payment was made on 16th September.‚Äù‚ÄúMany taxpayers had a harrowing time. It is only fair that they are not burdened with charges due to factors beyond their control -- irrespective of whether their payment was incomplete or they were unable to login. The CBDT‚Äôs Circular 5/2025, which gave relief for payments of TDS/TCS (tax deducted and collected at source) affected by similar issues, sets a precedent. Courts too have recognised such challenges and granted relief in non-compliances such as delay in return filings or document uploads caused by technical glitches. Taxpayers‚Äô intent to comply was evident as many transactions were reversed. A clarification from authorities would instil confidence in the system,‚Äù Ashish Karundia, founder of the CA firm Ashish Karundia & Co told ET.
Article Summary: A technical glitch in the Income Tax department ‚Äôs website prevented several companies from completing their advance tax payments by the September 15 deadline. Late payment of advance tax attracts interest at 1% per month. Since advance tax is paid quarterly, even a single day‚Äôs delay results in a 3% charge.

Article Title: Google Maps travel time accuracy: How exactly does it know the distance and time of your trip
Article Text:
How Google Maps calculates travel time exactly

Other factors that affect travel time

How accurate is it?

Why Google Maps is so reliable

Mapping distances and speed limits

Applying historical traffic patterns

Integrating real-time traffic updates

Using advanced routing algorithms

Considering transport mode, road type, and incidents

Continuously updating predictions dynamically





Have you ever marvelled at how Google Maps can tell you almost exactly how long your journey will take? It‚Äôs not magic; it is a combination of advanced technology, vast amounts of data, and clever algorithms. Google Maps doesn‚Äôt just measure the distance between two points. It considers speed limits, typical road speeds, and even the type of road you‚Äôre travelling on, whether a smooth highway or a busy city street. On top of that, it uses live traffic updates from millions of users, historical traffic patterns, and artificial intelligence predictions to give you highly accurate travel times. This dynamic system ensures that your estimated arrival time adjusts in real time if there is an accident, heavy traffic, or roadwork along the way.At its core, Google Maps measures the distance from your starting point to your destination using detailed digital maps. It then calculates travel time based on average speeds for each type of road. For example, highways generally allow higher speeds than local streets, so your journey is broken into segments with different speed estimates. The basic formula is simple:Travel Time = Distance √∑ Average SpeedHowever, the ‚Äúaverage speed‚Äù is not fixed. It is refined using data from previous trips and real-time conditions to make predictions far more accurate than simply following speed limits.Google Maps has collected years of information on traffic patterns from past trips. By analysing when and where congestion usually occurs, the app can predict how fast traffic will move at a particular time of day or day of the week. This helps the system anticipate delays before they happen, giving you a realistic estimate rather than just a ‚Äúdistance divided by speed‚Äù calculation.One of the most powerful features of Google Maps is its ability to see live traffic conditions. Users‚Äô smartphones with the app open anonymously send location and speed data. By analyzing this information, Google can detect traffic jams, accidents, or road closures and instantly adjust your route and travel time. This is why your arrival time can change while you are already on the road.Finding the fastest route is not as simple as choosing the shortest path. Google Maps uses advanced algorithms like Dijkstra‚Äôs algorithm and A search* to evaluate millions of possible routes. These algorithms consider distance, speed, traffic, road types, and other factors to determine the quickest path. The system also constantly re-evaluates your route based on new traffic data.Google Maps considers many additional factors to improve accuracy:Mode of transport: Walking, biking, driving, or public transit each have unique speed and route characteristics.Road types: Highways, main streets, and side roads all have different average speeds.Traffic incidents: Accidents, roadwork, or closures are factored in real time.Machine learning predictions: Google predicts future traffic patterns using AI, considering weather, events, and historical trends.Google Maps is impressively accurate. Studies and user experiences show that its travel time estimates often differ by only 1‚Äì2 minutes on average for normal trips. Accuracy may vary during extreme traffic or unpredictable events, but the app quickly adjusts estimates as conditions change.The key to Google Maps‚Äô reliability is its layered approach:This combination of technology, live data, and machine learning ensures that Google Maps can give you travel times that are both accurate and adaptive, making commuting and long trips easier to plan than ever before.
Article Summary: Google Maps measures the distance from your starting point to your destination using detailed digital maps. It then calculates travel time based on average speeds for each type of road. The ‚Äúaverage speed‚Äù is not fixed. It is refined using data from previous trips and real-time conditions to make predictions far more accurate than simply following speed limits.

Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg has now acknowledged the possibility of an AI-driven market bubble by drawing parallels to the dot-com era. Still, he argued that AI could be an exception if demand for increasingly capable models continues to expand.‚ÄúIf the models keep on growing in capability year-over-year and demand keeps growing, then maybe there is no collapse,‚Äù he added.Despite the risks, Meta CEO Zuckerberg is also emphasised that underinvestment poses a bigger danger than overspending.‚ÄúIf we end up misspending a couple hundred billion dollars, that‚Äôs going to be very unfortunate.But I would say the risk is higher on the other side,‚Äù he explained.‚ÄúIf we end up misspending a couple hundred billion dollars, that‚Äôs going to be very unfortunate. But I would say the risk is higher on the other side,‚Äù he explained.He warned that building too slowly could leave companies unprepared if superintelligence arrives sooner than expected:‚ÄúIf you build too slowly, and superintelligence is possible in three years but you built it out assuming it would be there in five years, then you‚Äôre out of position on what I think is going to be the most important technology.‚ÄùMeta has already pledged at least $600 billion through 2028 for U.S. data centers and AI infrastructure, alongside the launch of a superintelligence lab to recruit top researchers.

Article Title: US immigration authority clarifies: Trump‚Äôs new H-1B visa requirement applies only to‚Ä¶

Proclamation, Restriction on Entry of Certain Nonimmigrant Workers, H-1B

On September 19, 2025, the President issued a Proclamation, Restriction on Entry of Certain Nonimmigrant Workers, to address systemic abuse of H-1B nonimmigrant visas. Pursuant to sections 212(f) and 215(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), 8 U.S.C. 1182(1) and 1185(a), the entry into the United States of aliens as nonimmigrants to perform services in a specialty occupation under section 101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b) of the INA, 8 U.S.C. 1101(a)(15)(H)(i)(b), is restricted, except for those aliens whose petitions are accompanied or supplemented by a payment of $100,000. This guidance applies to H-1B employment-based petitions filed after 12:01 AM ET on September 21, 2025.

This proclamation only applies prospectively to petitions that have not yet been filed. All officers of United States Citizenship and Immigration Services shall ensure that their decisions are consistent with this guidance. The proclamation does not impact the ability of any current vim holder to travel to or from the United States.

cc: David V. Roy, Chief Counsel (A)

Many Indian IT firms have already reduced their reliance on H-1B visas to well below 50%, signalling the industry‚Äôs shift towards stronger offshore and near-shore delivery models.‚ÄúOver the past several years, Indian IT firms have significantly reduced their reliance on the H-1B visa, with filings dropping by over 50%. This shift is a result of our ongoing strategy to hire more locally, invest in automation, and enhance our global delivery models. While visa fees may change, the impact on our business will be minimal, as we‚Äôve already adapted to this evolving landscape,‚Äù CP Gurnani, founder & vice chairman, AionOS.What industry observers are arguing is how the new visa fee, if implemented, could reshape the IT talent landscape globally.Vivek Wadhwa, CEO of Vionix Biosciences and former distinguished fellow at Harvard Law School and Carnegie Mellon, warned of long-term consequences for the US.‚ÄúTrump‚Äôs $100,000 H-1B fee is economic suicide for America. It will force Indian talent to go home, taking with them skills, savings, and global experience. Indian engineers have been trapped in limbo for years because of endless visa backlogs. Trump has just pushed them to make the obvious choice: return home where opportunities are greater.‚Äù Wadhwa added that the reverse talent flow would benefit India enormously. ‚ÄúThey will bring capital, networks, and the knowhow of scaling companies globally.‚ÄùPhil Fersht, CEO of US-based HfS Research, said while the new policy‚Äôs practical longevity is questionable, there would be impacts to track. ‚ÄúThis policy may not survive in court or Congress, but the damage is already done. It has jolted the industry into fast-tracking automation and near-shoring. Even if the $100,000 fee is overturned, providers and clients will lock in new strategies that reduce reliance on H-1Bs. In effect, the policy acts as a catalyst. It may not last, but it will accelerate structural change in how global IT services are delivered.‚ÄùAmong Indian companies, steps to reduce H-1B reliance have been afoot for some time. IT major TCS has built a formidable onshore presence in North America with over 46,000 employees across 32 locations, including key hubs in New York, Edison, Cincinnati, Santa Clara, Phoenix, and Austin. Infosys employs 34,388 professionals in the Americas, while HCLTech has more than 23,000 employees in the US, with 75% of its workforce locally hired.Asked whether Trump‚Äôs return as US president would accelerate near-shore strategies to ensure uninterrupted delivery for clients, TCS CEO Krithivasan had said in Jan, ‚ÄúOn an annual basis, we get between 3,000 and 4,000 H-1B visas for a workforce of over 600,000. That‚Äôs a very small number. Even within the US, more than 50% of the workforce is locally hired. On an incremental hiring basis, we probably hire much more than 50% every year in the US compared to the H-1B workforce. So, our dependence on H-1B is quite limited. Near-shore exists because we sometimes want to provide sametime zone service to our customers. We are not particularly worried about any immigration reforms or changes in immigrant regulations.‚ÄùAlso read: Panic on board: $100k H-1B visa fee triggers flight chaos in US among Indian travellers - watch Infosys CFO Jayesh Sanghrajka reinforced this shift in Jan, explaining how the company has steadily reduced its visa dependency. ‚ÄúWe used to be at the 30% rate, but now we are at 24%. Within that, our nearshore has increased significantly. And within the US onsite population that we have, our H-1 independent folks are now over 60%. We have now built a pretty resilient model from that perspective. And we are, therefore, much more confident from where we are versus where we used to be earlier,‚Äù he said.On the other hand, venture capitalist Deedy Das, partner at Menlo Ventures, highlighted the implications on social media platform X: ‚ÄúMost BigTech companies have <15% of the workforce on H-1B... If you have to pay a $100k tax for 15k engineers that could be a $1.5B payout for a large company. This might push them to consider hiring less in the US and move offices offshore even faster than they already do. It creates a disincentive to attract the world‚Äôs smartest talent to the US. They have to pay a high education price and may now not be able to easily recoup it with a job. If the US ceases to attract the best talent, it drastically reduces its ability to innovate and grow the economy. It makes the US‚Äô global competitiveness a lot worse.‚ÄùThe Indian tech industry‚Äôs contributions to the US economy remain significant. According to a joint report by Nasscom and S&P Global, Indian IT firms employed 207,000 people in the US in 2021, with an average wage of $106,360. This represented a 22% increase over 2017. The report further noted that the Indian technology sector generated $103 billion in revenue from the US market in 2021. By supporting American enterprises, Indian IT firms indirectly generated a total of $396 billion in US sales output, supported 1.6 million jobs, and contributed more than $198 billion to the US economy.Against this backdrop, Trump‚Äôs new H-1B visa fee may act as a shortterm political lever, but its long-term effects could undermine US competitiveness while accelerating India‚Äôs role as a global hub for technology talent and innovation.
